text:
It has long been recognised (and one of the key reasons why countries like South Korea, Germany & Japan have been so successful) that long-term fixing and ring-fencing of an optimum allocation of education budget per pupil for schools (similar to what Gordon Brown invested in when he has PM before Cameron slashed it as part of austerity measures) improves the lives and wellbeing of not only children, but the long-term prospects of the country as a whole, including economic growth, entrepreneurship, innovation, employment, business success, etc.
Not only that, it has been shown to reduce long term Government expenditure on crime, unemployment, police, courts, prisons, mental health, physical health, obesity, etc. far beyond what the investment costs.
Having an agile and fully-funded world class education system (with healthy school meals for all) is a cornerstone to a nation's long-term success !

A Level & Scottish Highers are at a level equivalent to US undergraduate first & second year maths.
GCSE/ Standard Grade maths are equivalent to a US high school diploma/ GED level.

text:
Urgh. What the Prime Minister's doing isn't helpful. Maths engagement will only be solved fy fostering enjoyment of maths at the younger key stages. He'd do better in delaying formal education until the age of 6 and expanding the mathematics curriculum so that it is both engaging and practical for 6-11 years olds. 

What the media's doing isn't helpful. Trying to champion an "anti-maths" message only causes worry regarding maths and makes people less likely to want to achieve in it. 

This has all been so badly handled.
author: @Matthew-bu7fg

text:
I teach at maths and science at a GCSE tuition centre and honestly there is a problem. Kids in Yr 11 struggling with arithmetic is only the start of it. Its not the maths but the focused problem solving skills it teaches that are lacking.

Children at 16 who can't understand probability and statistics will struggle to make informed decisions.

While mathematical logic can't be applied to real life all the time, maths will also help with rational thinking.

Forcing all kids to do the A level maths curriculum as is won't help though. I'm sorry but no one needs to know how to differentiate and integrate functions.

Unless there is a plan for a "maths for everyday life" alternative which would focus on statistics, financial literacy and logical reasoning among other things, than this plan won't work.

text:
It has long been recognised (and one of the key reasons why countries like South Korea, Germany & Japan have been so successful) that long-term fixing and ring-fencing of an optimum allocation of school budget per pupil for schools (similar to what Gordon Brown invested in when he has PM before Cameron slashed it as part of austerity measures) improves the lives and wellbeing of not only children, but the long-term prospects of the country as a whole, including economic growth, entrepreneurship, innovation, employment, business success, etc.
Not only that, it has been shown to reduce long term Government expenditure on crime, unemployment, police, courts, prisons, mental health, physical health, obesity, etc. far beyond what the investment costs.
Having an agile and fully-funded world class education system (with healthy school meals for all) is a cornerstone to a nation's long-term success !
author: @SumiG_Playz

text:
There is a lot of hot air talked about school  "Maths". Maths as distinct from Arithmetic is an abstract subject that regardless of the misplaced enthusiasm from teachers, is very difficult for the average brain to comprehend. Algebra in particular is a "Black Art" and is only really available to a few gifted pupils. Its usefulness in modern-day workplaces is still limited. Vast numbers of Accountants and Quantity Surveyors rely on good numeracy, not abstract concepts.
The main overarching problem in society is control of personal finance and it's here where far more teaching is required. While we have large numbers of people who are more interested in running up credit bills for ephemeral junk, rather than things of value, we will continue to flounder.

text:
If you're teaching them binomials before they understand the basics, it won't matter how long you teach them, noone will engage with it and will leave school thicker and robbed of two years they could have specialised in something they care about. 

There are plenty of children who get to 10 years old, incapable of adding or subtracting. There are plenty of children unable to get higher than a D (equivalent) in GCSEs. If they are then told, your A levels include compulsory Maths, and that Maths is A level Maths, none of them will succeed, and all of them will be embittered. 

Education reform is very urgent and a long time coming. How to reform it is to ensure early engagement with learning and confirming basic general common knowledge and understanding. Which they wont do, because they treat school like childcare. 

That being said, there are plenty of things the government should be turning their attention to. Unless the education reforms are groundbreaking they are just a distraction from real issues, like the migrant crisis, overtaxation of small business, big state bloat leeches.

I don't believe this to be the right decision, to a degree 

I agree the courses needed work and more knowledge incorporated


But I think students spend enough time that is needed to do said courses


I think that A Levels and T Levels should stay separate since they're catered for different individuals goals

T is for Technical, some theory and more practical

A is for Academic which means that it's based on an exam and grade system with little to no practical work


Do both need improvement, probably. But there should be another alternative to simply just trying to combine both into one thing, and I don't think that would work well. So Rishi Sunak should try something else, but not this option

text: Tell me if something stands out in my grades, Maths, Physics, Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science grades of 8,9,8,8,8 and then 4,5 for English Language and English Literature. My brain cannot handle "English", it's not wired that way. I was so happy about leaving English in the past and this really allowed me to achieve good grades in A-Levels. Now imagine a student like me forced to take English further. They won't get any better at "English" and all you would do is divert their time and energy from their strong subjects towards subject that won't provide them any more value. I would personally be less happy and more stressed if this was to happen to me which would negatively impact my overall achievements. I say "English" because the "English" we are taught in school has nothing to do with the English we use day to day. If you want people to be more literate in Maths and English, provide them high value Maths and English in GCSEs. Then there are students who cannot handle "maths" the way way I cannot handle "English" the subject.

text:
A question: Is the story breaking in today's Guardian about Tory failure to back the schools catch-up plan developed by Sir Kevan Collins being directly responsible for the North-South disparities in exam results, not a case of underfunding that should forewarn Starmer that a policy agenda based primarily on affordability criteria - and that follows current Treasury orthodoxy - should not be allowed to overtake strategic importance if further harm is to be avoided?  

If there are strategic investment priorities that are critical to making progress on the deeply undermined public infrastructure and services, then is it not unavoidable that some there must be some spending priorities that cannot be sacrificed?  Is there a political case for long term borrowing, if the alternative is more of this sort of failure down the road?  Or is Starmer merely waiting for the Tory crash pile-ups to make his argument for him?

I refer to this breaking story in the Guardian today:

Ex-schools tsar blames Tories for north-south exam divide
Sir Kevan Collins says government failure to back his ¬£15bn post-Covid catch-up plan caused the stark disparity in this year‚Äôs English GCSE results

https://www.theguardian.com/education/2023/aug/27/ex-schools-tsar-blames-tories-for-north-south-exam-divide

I hate maths. Did engineering and now project management. Maths is important, but being able to make good judgement calls based on maths is real life. 

Things that put accountability into teenagers' hands from the minute they enter secondary school is what we should be doing. Those with independence should be allowed to study like its college and be given trust. Those who need/want a classroom should be in class with no more than ten other kids.  

Education is the development of understanding and character. Those who have built maturity and capability through testing themselves become experts and leaders. Maths is such a small element. Fund education properly.

text: There's not a single ounce of 'anti-maths mindset' in this country. Not only are maths-applied courses (business, computer science, engineering&tech) at least 50-60% of the top ten most studied at uk universities (with business being the top btw), maths is the most popular subject taken at A-levels. So already we find that he's full of shit but that's just scratching the surface. Boris Johnson said during the pandemic that people in certain arts related careers would have to 'retrain' to 'make a living'. Bearing in mind in 2022, the government decided to cut funds to Arts Council England Guidance of amounts going up to ¬£75 mil with another ¬£43.5 mil over the three subsequent years. This man has been (and is still trying to) scare young arts/humanities enthused pupils into believing they can't make a living and is trying to belittle arts and humanities careers in the UK. He's essentially remarking that people who study history, politics, philosophy, arts are essentially low achieving using the "oh the economy is bad" as nothing more than a rhetorical trick. He is a spineless, pusillanimous coward who's telling people who have passion in art/history/philosophy etc that careers in the arts and humanities are "lazy" and  "unachieving". However, he's merely scared that revisionist political movements who strive for social equality via passionate imagination/critical thought/creativity are going to destabilise his means of attaining income by trying to remove him and his friends (who want people to fear going broke by taking maths) from positions of power. This crepedarian know-nothing parasitic leach wants to keep fearing going broke through this. This reform needs to be killed with fire, burnt to ashes and have the very earths from which these ideas came salted so that they never grow again.

text:
Are we sure they're ignoring his plea for questions or maybe they can't think of any? Or maybe this conference was held in Winchester school and they didn't want to give him a hard time? Whatever - what a missed opportunity! They could've asked any number of questions, like:
"Hey Rishi when will you claw back the ¬£33bn to ¬£58bm worth of fraud from the tax havens so that junior doctors & nurses can be paid a fair wage?"
"Are you ever going to make the rich pay their fair share of tax?"
"Given the climate emergency do you think it is ethical to continue to subsidise fossil fuels?"
"You say you want growth: how does austerity and under investment in our public services achieve it?"
"Is it still the case you don't have working class friends?"
"Given how much British people are struggling to make ends meet, how is it right that the King's coronation is being paid for by the public?"
"When you said "This will be a government of integrity accountability and professionalism at every level", since then do you think you've kept your promise?"

text: For those of us aged over 50, Civics Courses were encouraged for those leaving school.  They sounded very boring but were actually really useful.  They would take place towards the end of the academic year, once all the exams had been completed.  I remember mine quite well.  We had local Councillors pay visits to tell us how local councils work and what type of elections took place.  A representative from a bank came in and explained different accounts, how loans and mortgages work and we occasionally had a former pupil come in to describe what they had done since leaving school.  Afternoons were generally spent on practical things.  How to change the fuse in a plug.  How to fix a gate or a fence.  How to change a wheel on a car.  How to do the laundry. It was all very relaxed but above all it was informative.  That's the sort of 16+ we need  The sort where kids can avoid being branded as academic idiots.

text:
Hi Phil.  You have perhaps missed two elephants in the room.
The first is the school leaving age.  Does this poilcy mean he plans to raise it to 18?  Two more boring years for the less academically minded "young adults".
The second is that with the school leaving age still at 16, then those who would pursue non maths/science courses will be discouraged from doing so by the compulsory maths (oh no not more maths!).
We are of course ignoring the forbidden subject that for everyone with an IQ greater than 120, there is someone with an IQ less than 80.  Whilst I would never suggest a return to the secondary moderns and so on, it is likely that a significant portion of the population would not benefit from further acedemic education.
That you say that students up to GCSE level can understand maths if it phrased into an exam question is a grave inditment on the education system that they are taught to pass exams not taught to understand the subject.
I think you are right to think this policy "vapourware".

text:
Some people are simply not good at maths. There are many possible reasons why someone might not be good at maths. Some people may have learning disabilities that make it difficult for them to understand mathematical concepts. Others may have had negative experiences with math in the past, which have caused them to develop a fear or anxiety around the subject. Still others may simply have a natural lack of aptitude for math. Lack of aptitude is important. I was not great at maths in school. I got my GCSE and gave up on the subject. Others may not even achieve a good GCSE result, so why force them to study something which they are probably going to fail at? This sets up a wave of demoralised students. This may cause them to cease their studies due to frustration. This cannot be good. Also, if you are going to force people to study subjects rooted in logic, why not add coding to the mix? Surely that is a good 21st century skill.
As far as 21st century skills are concerned, why not teach Critical Thinking? 

 Critical thinking is a mental process that involves carefully evaluating information and considering options before making a decision. It involves the ability to think logically and objectively, and to analyze and evaluate arguments and evidence in order to reach a well-reasoned conclusion. It is an essential skill that can be applied to many different areas of life, including problem-solving, decision-making, and evaluating information. Critical thinking requires an open mind and the willingness to consider multiple perspectives on an issue, as well as the ability to identify biases and assumptions that may affect one's thinking. It is an important skill to develop as it can help you to become a more effective and rational thinker, and to make better decisions in your personal and professional life.

I suppose that if this was taught, no-one would ever vote Conservative!


Additionally, a lack of access to quality maths education can also contribute to someone's difficulty with the subject. This is a salient point, where are they going to get the additional maths teachers from? Education already struggles with recruitment and retention of teachers. 

It's important to note that anyone can improve their maths skills with effort and practice, and that there are many resources available to help people learn math at their own pace. So if you want to improve your maths skills, get a tutor, even watch YouTube videos or buy a course on Udemy or another learning platform. There are some high-quality resources available these days.

The Government should consider redesigning the education system so it is fit for purpose in the 21st Century. My background is in second language teaching. The existing system of studying grammar and vocabulary, reading texts, listening to audio and writing essays or reports simply does not work. The purpose of a language is to allow communication. In order to communicate, we speak. Yet language classes have little or no focus on the oral production of language. Students learn about things like modal verbs, defining and non-defining relative clauses and so on, but they don‚Äôt learn how to speak. I used the preposition ‚Äúabout‚Äù deliberately because in our system, the students learn about language. We do not produce effective communicators.

text: I resat maths a few times. First time I did a maths exam in school, I got an E. Then I resat and got a D. Then I went to college and resat maths a few times, over the course of five consecutive years and got Ds and Es. Eventually, I did a level 2 qualification in application of number, which is equivalent of a C grade at GCSE. English was a similar story. In school, I got E in literature and language, although the first language exam result was definitely contributed to by the exam board changing the exam at the last minute, so the whole year group was completely unprepared for it. After a resit, I got a D. Then in college, I got Ds and Es again, with the exception being in my last year at college, in which I got a B. author: @emoakland5339

text:
I gave up believing anything this government promises a very long time ago. I still can't get a proper in-person GP appointment which tells me all I need to know about this shower. 

With regard to mathematics, I can quite understand the presenter's emphasis on practical numeracy - fair enough. Bit why not try and deliver the intrinsic interest of the subject as well? People read poetry and novels or watch plays for enjoyment and general enrichment (and that's supposedly at least why these things are taught at school), but hardly ever do I hear of the same being done with  mathematics. 

Mathematics is about patterns and the patterns behind patterns. Who can fail to be moved by the Mandelbrot Set, the weird Koch Curve, the sheer elegance of conic sections when visualised (as well as their use in engineering and physics). Or even the patterns in the boring multiplication tables grid. Not just 9, 18, 27, 36... (falling units, rising tens...) but the 8x (cycles endings in 8, 6, 4, 2, 0, 8...). Then ask the class what the 7's do. Les obvious, but there is still an elegant pattern to the final digits - (0)**, 7, 4, 1, 8,5,2, 9,6,3,0,7, 4, 1... i.e. 0 starts the new cycle. Maybe here you could use Cuisenaire rods to help. Might help memorisation, too. In fact the final digits in any base (e.g. 12, 13, hexadecimal, 64...) are an application of arithmetic modulo that base. (Think it out - e.g. look up 'modulo', 'clock arithmetic' and counting bases other than 10 online and see if you can draw similar conclusions!). I'm aware this latter is flies a bit high for primary classrooms. Note however that a lot of code-breaking from Bletchley Park to the present day relies on finding patterns in numbers and statistics. One enterprising maths teacher teamed up with her opposite number in the history department and had her Year 8 class transported back to Bletchley Park during WW2. She then devised messages for the learners to decode using methods appropriate to their abilities. I hope the Ukrainians have something like Bletchley Park now.

I could go on to considerable length but I hope this gives a glimpse of mathematics being interesting for its own sake - although it's also extremely useful in all areas of life from figuring out recipes and the weekly housekeeping budget to spotting Government and corporate bullsh*t - and in understanding all engineering design. And I've found that my  'useful' maths has been greatly enhanced by finding it fascinating. Not every learner will react like me, but if intrinsic interest rather than test results could be pushed a bit harder then at least learners would see the subject for what it really is. 

I strongly recommend 'A Mathematician's Lament' by Dr Paul Lockhart, available online and as a book. He's a PhD who went back to the classroom and his conclusions on mathematics teaching would make the present lot of charlatans, slick biz-persons and con-artists very uncomfortable even though written up ten or twelve years ago! I think a lot of the teaching profession do their best (e.g. maths clubs, intelligent use of online videos and paperwork), but the system is against them.

Finally. I was talking recently at a reunion to a distinguished Old Boy of my school who'd been taught maths in the private sector in the Golden Age of the 1950s (all bow, all scrape!). Unfortunately his 'teacher's method of ensuring retention was sometimes picking on students who hadn't grasped it and sometimes I think liberal use of a blackboard rubber or similar as a missile. Result - gentleman hated and feared mathematics. Then came the twist - he said he often saw patterns in scenes and objects round about him, more or less subconsciously... AARGGHH! Because that's what real mathematics is about! 


**7 times 0 is 0 - anything times zero is zero (including Rishi's credibility!). More formally, 'for all A members of the set R of real numbers, A x 0=0'.

text:
The problem is compounded in schools by a lack of qualified teachers, ie people who haven't been trained specifically in the relevant subject. How would you like it, for example, if your dentist had a degree in science but no dentistry qualification? Or the person teaching your child maths whose degree was in Biology? This decline in professional standards is euphemistically called "the staffing-led curriculum" which, briefly put, means that anyone on the school's staff who, say, had some timetable slack and once did piano to Grade 6 as a child but whose degree was in History could be dragooned into teaching Music. This, in turn, is further exacerbated  by the government doing away with Qualified Teacher status, which opens the door to any Tom, Dick or Harry. The teaching profession is hard-working, committed and conscientious but treated with contempt by the current government. My own degree was in Modern Languages  - specifically, French and German  - but in my 37 years of teaching  (I'm retired, thankfully), I have "taught" Music, Latin, Russian, English and RE for various periods of time. My input must have been much less than that of specialist teachers and I hope it didn‚Äôt disadvantage the students. The situation is unacceptable but that old Blairite mantra "Education,  Education, Education" is still valid but, alas, given mere lip service by the current government. Look, if it's not too depressing or painful, at the Tories' appointments to the key post of Secretary of State for Education in recent memory and especially that of that spectacularly stupid, incompetent and ignorant former fireplace salesman whose staggering cockups were rewarded with a knighthood. A work of fiction would be hard pressed to equal this for credibility.  
And as for Maths up to the age of 18, why? Admittedly, I failed O-level Maths 3 times but I can add, multiply, subtract, and divide,  I can work out how many cans of paint I need to buy to paint the lounge, add up my bill in a restaurant and add the right percentage of tip to add to the bill. I learned about sines, cosines, quadratic equations, differential calculus and geometry but none of this has made the slightest impact on my day-to-day life. In other words. Sunak is talking empty tosh. He is a doomed prime minister, a man whose canoe is up a creek, the paddle missing and who is scrabbling around for a way out by thinking up mind-blowingly irrelevant initiatives instead of present a dynamic vision and a route-map to carry it through.

We forgot the difference between "belief" and "knowledge".  These are two sets of ideas; they are opposite in every way.  Any idea can be a "belief" idea.  Until a human measures it.  Once the idea is repeatable, then it becomes "knowledge".  The only way to measure for repeatability is to use the tool that does that: math.  If one could "instinct" a wheel, elephants would have wheels.  The counting is required.

If someone "lawyers" you wheel and you get in the car, you will die.  You can't put a trian wheel on a car everyone will die, the counting is required.  Guessing sucks and makes next to nothing.

Individual choice making at the virus.  A bacteria infects an individual.  The virus infects a group, called a discrete object.  Using discrete mathematics, we can measure what will likely happen at the virus (not you) or the group (again not you).  Dr. Rand Paul and Desantis make GROUP choices as individuals.  We know this because it is a measurable idea.  Their "individually choice making" idea is false.  

The idea they are making an individual choice as an individual, is false, provably.  See all the dead people.  Mostly from individual choice making.  That's difference between "belief" and "knowledge" all the dead people.

text:
There is a considerable shortage of teachers - especially maths teachers - in England and Wales. Teachers in both Primary and Seconday schools have to cope with large class sizes and a huge work-load, and are always having to get children to pass various tests (SATS) rather than being free to teach the underlying *principles* involved. Teaching in state schools in the UK is a high-stress job, and the pay is far from ideal - hence the shortage of teachers. 

So along with the valid points about the type of maths taught, and to what level, the problem of capacity is by far the greatest. Hence this government policy will never happen under a Tory government. 

Of course, independent schools (unhelpfully known as Publid Schools) are mostly far better funded, have good quality teachers, teaching small class sizes, with good resources for subjects such as science and music - unlike state schools, which are run on a shoestring, and which are all struggling to be able to pay for the teachers and teaching hours which the law demands that they do. 

And as long as there are well-funded independent schools for the rich elite to send their children, the Tories have ZERO interest in properly funding state education. They see this as pandering to the 'plebs.' The Tory mindset is that all the little brats of the lower orders need to do is to have minimal education - indeed, if the Tories could get away with sending children to work up chimneys or down mines, that would be just fine. 

After all, since 2010 under Tory rule there are now around 4 million children in food poverty - so the Tories are halfway towards their objective already. Here's a link:
https://www.bigissue.com/news/social-justice/food-poverty-in-the-uk-the-causes-figures-and-solutions/

text:
As someone who went through high school from 2013-2017, Maths is not the issue, (If they wanted to increase students learning maths. lose what i call "Useless lessons" PE/RS, I can understand why people like PE But RS is useless.) I actually liked Maths but the issue where i went to high school is that it had mainly two issues.
1. Continuity, i had a maths teacher from i think to year 8 to year 10 who was brilliant, then in year 11 he left and was replaced by a brand new teacher who was a nice guy but because he was new he was hated by most of the students so he spent most of his lessons trying to calm the class down.
2. Money, my school was fairly underfunded. i was diagnosed with a learning disability during primary school and when i went to high my parents sent the notes and diagnosis to the school and they kept on messing up, i remember when i had to do something arty and i couldn't do it because i can't really write with this learning Disability, so my teacher just kept on forcing me to do it until i literally shouted at her that i couldn't do it (Which was weird because I'm normally very quite in a class) 
Another issue was when i was doing geography which is something i really like during the first year in GCSE they just transferred me from Geography to Prince's trust because they thought "It would be easier" Despite princes trust being a very sociable thing it sounded like hell for me. but the issue was when i shouted this at her and my parents were properly annoyed at them i now realise that they probably had no idea what we were talking about, which indicates that no training for students with learning disabilities was given to them

text:
There still seems to be people who think that 'A-levels' have not been dumbed down. In the case of mathematics the evidence for this is overwhelming so I think it's worth demonstrating that.

It is common practice at many universities to give the same standard maths test to all engineering, physics and maths students when they first arrive in order to discover any gaps in their knowledge so that first year maths courses can be adjusted to fill in any weak areas. Knowing the students A-level result in Maths and using the test result gives the following:

For a 1991 cohort at Coventry University, the scores of those who got N (a fail) in A-level maths in 1991, (some soft sciences were open to those who failed A-level maths), were virtually identical to those who got a grade C in 1997. And the continuation of the same study revealed that 1991 N-graders were equivalent to 1999 B-graders. In general, then, on certain basic mathematical skills, A-level standards in maths are dropping one grade every two years. And in a diagnostic test given at York University over 15 years, and reported separately in 2001, this finding is corroborated. A student with an A grade at A-level now had a score on the test which would have put him or her near the bottom of the cohort in 1986, and, even more striking perhaps, an average grade B student at A-level was able to score only marginally better on the York test than could have been done by random guessing.

From the university of Sussex: 
Students skills have gradually declined over the years. As the test has been used since the 1970s (with some small changes during the 1980s due to A-Level curriculum changes), some statistical data is available to indicate this. A two page memorandum was circulated inside the department in 1998.
This memorandum indicated that the mean of correct responses (out of 30 questions) fell from 25 to 18.5 between the mid-1980s and the mid-1990s.

"Algebraic skills amongst math A level students have declined to such an extent that the manipulation of powers and logarithms is a dark mystery to many" (we used to call it O-level Maths in my day).

See for example "Historical Study of Correlation between  A-Level Grades and Subsequent Performance Ken Todd  University of York". The study in that case runs from 1985 to 2001, but since pass rates have continued to increase since 2001 I don't believe things are any different.

One university (I forget which one) had to abandon its test in 2000 as too difficult. None of this is recent. Standards have continued to decline and all universities have now had to abandon their standard maths test for STEM students and concentrate on teaching remedial classes to bring students up to the old A-level standard.

author: @unchilgisam

text: The colour thing in the beginning represent the decomposition of all numbers into powers and product of prime numbers, each prime number has a specific colour forming a full circle of this unique colour, sometimes the portions of circles in non prime numbers are differentiated, like 11 and 17 in the numbers 33 and 34 perhaps because the colours are too similar or to give an hint, the number of portions of circles of the same colour represent the power of the associated prime number and when we do the product of all portions of the circle we get the number we're looking for, for exemple, 60 has two orange portions of circles representing 2x2=2¬≤ and one green portion of circle representing 3¬π so 3,and the last blue one represent 5¬π so five, u take the product of them so 2¬≤x5x3=60, u can do the same with each number, btw, the number 1 has a white circle, representing the fact it is a multiple of all numbers as white contains all colours, but at the same time it does not have its own colours, because it is not a prime number.

text: I'll tell you the truth, I love math, and always wanted to teach it, but when I got the opportunity to tutor 2 cognitively disabled adults in basic maths, I realized it's really, really, really hard to get someone to figure out WHY something is true, disheartened, I decide to revisit this video, right now I'm planning in my head the question needed to trigger the thinking that leads to understanding basic division. If this goes well, then your video has made an amazing impact on the life of not 1, but 2 (and counting me, 3) disabled people. So thank you

author: @edenbetterfarms

text:
I completely disagree with your technique. My technique is quite different:

1.  First write sth in prose , like suppose .... That should exert mind of the learner very little. Like an aero plane start moving on the runway. 

This is what an ingenous teacher do at the start of the lecture. 

2.  Little-by-little give small challenges to the learner. For this purpose, give more than enough time to the learner. Show your pleasure when he succeeds. Continue likewise aero plane's runway movement in teaching. 

3.  Escape aero plane's mid air movement until the final result is obtained.

With these techniques the learner never gets disinterested. It enables the learner  to taste the joy of discovering something valuable.
author: @rajnikantsinha2636

author: @visanthnair121

text: All those with plain colors are prime numbers, rest all are representing the mix of colors of prime numbers because prime numbers are the fundamental building blocks of other numbers. Ultimately the entire pattern represents the ‚ÄúFundamental Theory of Arithmetic‚Äù
author: @visanthnair121

text:
1 - grey
2 - orange
3 - green
4 = 2x2 - 2 orange
5 - blue
6 = 3x2 - orange and green
7 - purple
8 = 2x2x2 - 3 orange
.
.
.
.
.

text: I had some great teachers of math in elementary school who helped me understand math, and geometry, from the get go.  However, i do have an amazing memory so, memorizing formulas, for me, was a piece of cake.  Memorizing arithmetic tables was facilitated by my grandmother drilling them before class.  I still remember all geometry formulas for areas and perimeters of regular polygons that I learned in 3rd grade.  My high school teacher for arithmetic, algebra, geometry and trigonometry did make us recite formulas and they stuck.  I can recite back to you binomial expansions, factorization of simple polynomials, geometry formulas, trigonometric definitions and identities.  I, then, went to engineering college and I can still recall formulas for derivatives of products and quotients, the chain rule, L‚ÄôHopital‚Äôs ruble for limits, tables of derivatives, tables of anti derivatives, integration by substitution, integration by parts, formulas from multi variate calculus, lineal algebra, vector analysis, and differential equations.  I still remember all the basic definitions of statistics of samples, and the most common parametric probability distributions from my college years.  Definitely understand math very well, but train your memory also, is a great combination.

text: I'm an engineer turned teacher.     Not to knock teachers, but what I find is that "math teachers" are really good at working problems and seem to lack understanding of the utility of math.  Their understanding is academic, where as an engineer or mathematician is a practitioner of math.  I believe that is the problem.  They don't often explain the why or the math, verses the how.
author: @robertprice9052

text: I‚Äôve recently decided I want to become an aerospace engineer, but the problem I‚Äôve ran into is that I‚Äôm bad at math and don‚Äôt even have my GED yet. But the same day that I decided I knew what I wanted to do for a career, I decided I was going to put my nose to the grindstone and actually figure out how to become better at math as a whole. So far I‚Äôve been studying around 2 to 6 hours a day and I decided to start at the very beginning of basic arithmetic, and work my way up to eventually understanding parts of Physics in college. So far in just three days I‚Äôm already at a 9th grade level of math starting from 1st grade math. And this is all just to say that your video is SUPER accurate. It‚Äôs not about memorizing math, it‚Äôs about understanding math. Once I learned again from the ground up it all made more sense. And I‚Äôve since learned to fall in love with math. Good luck to anyone else on the same journey!

text: Years ago, My daughter was having trouble understanding fractions as being taught in school. Once I understood her confusion, it was easy. I explained a fraction. The number on the bottom is and object and how many times it has been cut into pieces. The number on top is how many of those pieces you have. We did the typical cut up apple thing on our counter and BOOM! she got it! 10 minutes. She was 10 and looked at me and said really, it's that simple? I said yup.

text: The first problem could be solved using pythagorean theorem. The diameter of the white circle incasing the red/inner square happens to be equal to the side of the blue/outer square, and the hypotenuse of the red/inner square. This is the reason why your 45 degrees rotation and subdividing of the outer square into 4 works. But I have to say, it was very cool that you found such a unique visually geometric way of solving that problem!

author: @milkieeshazee

text:
I remember at age 14 I read about perspective in drawing. If a rectangular window which is vertically divided into 2 equal parts shall be drawn so that one end, nearer us, will be higher in the drawing than the far end, where shall you put the division? The nearer half must be drawn broader than the one farther away, but where exactly shall we place the division? A simple and elegant solution is to draw the 2 diagonals - where they meet is the right place. What if the window has 4 equal parts? Simply repeat the process on each half.
Now, 60 years later, I happened to think: "What if the window has 3 equal parts?" And using some creativity I solved it. Try it! You have probably never seen any formula or algorithm for this, so you must think creatively!
(Trisecting an angle is impossible, but not a window!)
author: @l.h.308

text:
I admit the solution to the circle in the square is ingenious; so doesn't that mean only an idiotic teacher would even come up with a problem like that? And how does this make any of the countless other millions of nightmareishly obscure and equally intentionally obtuse math problems any easier to solve? E.g. the fantasy problems like "one train leaves Chicago at 8:10" etc., which no human in the history of the real world has ever had to solve?üòÇ

Sorry, I'm coming off as too critical. I agree UNDERSTANDing math rather than just memorizing formulas is the key to success therein. Also, LIKEing math helps, as well as giving it a practical context. E.g. I wanted to measure the height of the tree in my front yard so I learned trigonometry in one day, having been fully motivated to do so. Later I wanted to figure out how many atoms are in the universe (surprisingly not that hard to figure outüòé)
On the other hand, quadratic equations...don't get me started. Whoever invented those should be given a blanket party like Vincent D'Onofrio in "Full Metal Jacket."
But I kid.üòÇ
Anywayyyyyyy...keep up the good work! üëçüëèüëèüëèüëèü§©

text:
Hey, Amy. Just came across your channel and it's amazing! ü§©

I struggle with maths and science subjects generally (probably because of the gap year I took after secondary school). But now that I've begun university, I often find it hard to study school material for long periods, I easily get distracted, demotivated when studying physics, chemistry or maths, and I'M VERY, VERY SLOW, making my study sessions last very long with me only doing like 5 practice questions in my 4 pomodoro study sessions (that I probably didn't even understand well).

Could you, please, suggest apps for me to use - aside from Quizlet, Khan Academy, Anki - or suggest how I can use these ones better to suit my Nigerian university's curriculum, and give me advice for my very slow, time-consuming pace of learning that leads to my demotivation?

text: These tricks work in real life.  That red-square, blue-square problem could be a real-life instance, but every trick fails if you can't show your work to the teacher.  My algebra teachers were no good at real-life, so I didn't do well with math until I didn't need to show my work.  I was too busy working for the grade, rather than the skill, to be good in math while I was a student, but that same student got a solid A in his electronics class - which was all math to be proven with circuitry.  I still had to show my work, but it was easy real life stuff that could be demonstrated off-paper.

author: @VIEW-ut3bu

text: here are some key tips: 1. math isn't metaphysics (it can help you add apples but it can't tell you what an apple is) 2. all of math is just the addition and/or subtraction of quantities/magnitudes and it creates a bunch of shortcuts that mean the same thing (3+3+3 = 3x3 = 3 squared) 3. zero isn't a number it's a placeholder, which is why you can't add/subtract/multiply/divide by zero. 4. the point of math is to help us predict a future outcome so that we can make better decisions in the present. 5. calculus is the reason you're learning algebra and calculus is just a (rate) change in quantity/magnitude over time (instead of 3+3+3 it's 3+2+1) 5. you'll be expected to learn how to translate language into a math equation so practice interpreting what it means when the store says 30% 'off' (move the decimal over two, multiply by .3 then subtract that result from the original amount) 6. don't feel bad about not understanding something.. it took humanity over 100k years to develop what you're learning so it's not reasonable to expect 18 year olds to be more competent than the sum total of the brightest people in human history.

author: @olly8113

text:
There are three parts too good math I reckon. Firstly, knowing that every symbol in math is a mix of plus, minus, add and divide. Secondly, knowing that algebra is the rules of mathematics, and you cannot do the formulas without knowing algebra. And thirdly is the concept, having someone explain it to you so you understand the nature of the problem, so that you can visualize it in the mind; As in this video. If you have a failure in the first two, then the problem is likely the student. And if you have a failure of the third, then the problem is likely the teacher. This is the way I see it.

The problem for the student is most likely, to call out the teacher, they need a good knowledge base from the first two. But if you explain all three to a student, I reckon they should be able to skip the teacher, and discover these things on their own. There should be enough resources out there these days. They just need to swallow a bit of pride, especially if their problem is the first problem I mentioned.

So, I agree with concept in this video. But I would not call them hacks. Calling them hacks I reckon likely makes the student fell hopeless. I would call them being taught to visualize.

text:
*Extreme Perceptions and The Magic*
General methods solve all problems but as a result they are also *complex* .
Special methods solve specific problems and as a result look very *simple* .
Your perception of math (either too easy or too hard but nothing in between) is shaped by your (not so or insightful) experiences (usually very good vs. very bad) solving math problems.

text:
Here's how I approached the problem:
Let the side of the red square= a and blue square= b 
To find: (a^2)/(b^2).
Now to reduce the variables in the equation I let a = 1 as no specific value is given, (even if you let a to be something else, since we are finding ratios here, it'll always reduce to the simplest form. )
now we need to find 1/(b^2).
Notice that the circle has its diameter equal to the hypotenuse of the red square. 
=> using the Pythagoras theorem we have diameter = ‚àö(1^2+1^2) = ‚àö2. 
Diameter of the circle is equal to the side of the blue square. Therefore we have, b =‚àö2 and b^2 = 2. Hence 1/(b^2) = 1/2 .

author: @parkavenue6970

text:
This problem was quite easy, I will explain my approach for anyone interested. I started out by simply labeling the inner side length a, and the outer side length c, and used the Pythagorean theorem to get c^2 in terms of a^2 (c^2 = a^2 / 2). The ratio of the areas is simply c^2 / a^2, so using what we just found this gives us (a^2 / 2) / a^2, and the a^2 here cancel leaving us with 1/2.

The problem, just like many others, becomes elementary when you apply tools such as Pythagoras and geometric relationships. You simply have to learn intuitively when to use each tool. The basic mathematical tools will take you very far if you are proficient in using them.

text:
hi , the video was amazing .. i wanted to share what else helped me . often times we straightly jump to solving questions of the chapter which makes us bored and leaves us wondering ,, instead divide the chapter in chunks , suppose we are handling derivatives so you can start like the first thing is 
f'(x) = nx^n-1 and then practice the type of questions around this formula ... 
i also suggest deriving trigonometric and calculas formulas to understand their origin and retain them better also dig a bit deeper to understand why we made such topic , example: calculas was develped to calculate what speed , velocities or any other sort of motion on an instant such as calculating the speed at 0.000000001 sec , we tend to take limit tends to zero for this ,which implies that time is approaching 0 but cannot be exact zero itself . maths is a language trust me , the more you speak it (practice it ) the more u get it .. but the practice must be mindful .

Till grade 8th math was easy for me. I used to sit in the class solving the same exercises for the 2nd or 3rd time which the teacher would start for the first time. And the teacher would call us to solve one the board therefore some of my classmates that sat close to me would ask me to solve for them and then they would memorize it and paste it exactly on the board. I would just wonder why did they even do that, like it's not something so hard. But now I just sit in the class, looking around and watch my classmates solving problems effortlessly. While i just question myself that how is everyone so clear about it whereas I'm like a lost child that absolutely has no idea. 
It's so frustrating to think that something i was best at is now the thing I'm worst at.

text:
Veil's Summary Notes:

This is How To ACE Math Step-By-Step.

- It's not about how many formulas you know. Instead, it's all about your problem solving skills and math sense.

But let's start with problem solving.

- Problem = Anything that humans pretend to have a missing piece of information to.
- Solution = That 'missing' piece of information which was never missing to begin with. 
- So To solve a problem, all you have to do is express the connections of this missing piece of information that isn't really missing, but always existed within the problem's context, yet people pretend it is missing just for the sake of challenging our mental capabilities.

Getting back to math sense, don't just learn excessive amounts of formulas without understanding HOW to use them in the first place. That's where your math sense comes in. 

Note: Math Sense = Math Skills.

The greater your Math Sense, the less you need to memorize.

Your Math Sense is basically the Cheat skill that will help you solve ANY Problem that comes your way in Math.

This is HOW You Acquire it;


1. Prioritize Understanding Over Memorizing.

For example, for the square root of 25, don't worry about memorizing the fact that; "the square root of 25 is 5."

Instead, focus on understanding the actual step by step process you need to take, to find the "square root" of something.

In other words, focus on understanding the meanings of each symbols and terms, especially the steps they require you to take.

Once you do understand these MAiN symbols/figures and what steps they require you to take, then you can do practice problems with ease.

You don't need to use any advanced memorization techniques once you understand, because when you do practice problems or your homeworks and assignments, then these operations will become engraved in your memory, whether you like it or not!


2. Break Your Math Problem into Parts.

Usually, we don't understand the foundations behind bigger math problems, that's why we tend to get stuck. Therefore, doing this will help spot our gaps in knowledge.

We know when we lack a certain knowledge when we look at the individual parts within the problem, and go, "huh?"

If you don't understand some parts within that problem, then break those parts down even further untill you spot familiar concepts you can use to build on your understanding.

If you break down the parts within a problem, but still don't understand those parts, then KEEP Breaking Those Parts Down Further! Keep breaking them down to something sooo basic, that it is impossible for you to NOT understand it.


3. Review Fundamentals on a Deeper Level.

After you've understood the fundamentals of each parts within the problem on the previous step, now is the time to solidify those concepts!

Watch some extra videos or do some extra research to clarify why the steps work, as well as their origins.

This will deepen your understanding.

You can also do practice problems to test, strengthen, and gain feedback for your understanding. Either use materials provided by your teachers or find free resources online.

Note that these are fundamental problems and NOT similar to the original problem you were dealing with. These little problems are to help you gain an basic understanding inorder to add to the original problem you were working on. For example, you'll work on 1+1=2 as your fundamental problems before moving to your original problem, which could be something like 12+13=25.

Repeat this step as much as you feel like it. Your internal feeling of certainty will be your guide.


4. Put The Pieces Together, and Then Reference The Solution.

Basically, try solving the original question yourself, as well as others similar to it once you've nailed the fundamental practice problems. 

Do this without looking at the answer key.

If you get to a part and feel stuck, you still must NOT look at the answer key... Yet.

Because the mental strain you feel is How your brain forces itself to access the recent understandings you've just created during the first few steps leading up to here.

Staying in this state of discomfort whilst forcing yourself to figure it out (even if your answer key is right on the next page) will pay dividends later toward your Math Sense.

Only after a long while (over 20 minutes of being stuck on the same step) do you check the answe key. But before that, try do the following within your 20 minutes;

A) Write down everything you know that could be relevant.
B) Draw connections between what you know. You can use arrows or lines to show these.
C) Make your best attempt, showcasing the full thought process you have regarding the potential solution. Give your best guess here.

After doing these 3 do you check the answer key. You can then compare the provided solutions against your own, and  see how similar or different they are.

This is where the problem-solving skills get built, and your Math Sense as well.

Lastly, Math is NOT Memorizing. 
Knowing HOW Math Works will make you the master of your math class, and NOT the victim of difficult equations.

. . .

PS; If you want EVEN BETTER and MORE ORGANISED Study Tips Than This, then Check This Link ;-)

https://mailchi.mp/03cf88cc0a3c/7rpfce7bqy

text:
Study presents new method for explainable AI
by Martina M√ºller , Fraunhofer-Gesellschaft
 New method for explainable AI
CRP method. Credit: Fraunhofer HHI

Artificial intelligence is already in widespread use, yet it is still difficult to understand how an AI system reaches its decisions. Scientists at the Fraunhofer Heinrich-Hertz-Institut (HHI) and the Berlin Institute for the Foundations of Learning and Data (BIFOLD) at TU Berlin have collaborated for many years to make AI explainable. Now the scientists led by Prof. Thomas Wiegand (Fraunhofer HHI, BIFOLD), Prof. Wojciech Samek (Fraunhofer HHI, BIFOLD) and Dr. Sebastian Lapuschkin (Fraunhofer HHI) have achieved another milestone.

In their paper "From attribution maps to human-understandable explanations through concept relevance propagation," the researchers present concept relevance propagation (CRP), a new method that can explain individual AI decisions as concepts understandable to humans. The paper has now been published in Nature Machine Intelligence.

AI systems are largely black boxes: It is usually not comprehensible to humans how an AI arrives at a certain decision. CRP is a state-of-the-art explanatory method for deep neural networks that complements and deepens existing explanatory models. In doing so, CRP reveals not only the characteristics of the input that are relevant to the decision made, but also the concepts the AI used, the location where they are represented in the input, and which parts of the neural network are responsible for them.

Thus, CRP is able to explain individual decisions made by an AI using concepts that are understandable to humans. As a result, this research sets an entirely new standard for the evaluation of and interaction with AI.

For the first time, this approach to explainability takes a look at the entire prediction process of an AI‚Äîall the way from input to output. In recent years, the research team has already developed various methods for using so-called heat maps to explain how AI algorithms reach their decisions.

The heat maps highlight specific areas in an image that are particularly relevant to the decision made. This method has become known as layer-wise relevance propagation (LRP). The importance of this type of explainability is enormous, as it allows us to understand whether an AI is actually making decisions based on sound reasoning or whether it has merely learned shortcut strategies and is thus cheating.

The new CRP method draws on layer-wise relevance propagation. "AI image recognition is a good example of this," says Prof. Wojciech Samek, head of the Artificial Intelligence department at Fraunhofer HHI, professor of Machine Learning and Communications at TU Berlin, and BIFOLD Fellow. "On the input level, CRP labels which pixels within an image are most relevant for the AI decision process. This is an important step in understanding an AI's decisions, but it doesn't explain the underlying concept of why the AI considers those exact pixels."

For comparison, when humans see a black-and-white striped surface, they don't automatically recognize a zebra. To do so, they also need information such as four legs, hooves, tail, etc. Ultimately, they combine the information of the pixels (black and white) with the concept of animal.

"CRP transfers the explanation from the input space, where the image with all its pixels is located, to the semantically enriched concept space formed by higher layers of the neural network," states Dr. Sebastian Lapuschkin, head of the research group Explainable Artificial Intelligence at Fraunhofer HHI, elaborating on the new method.

"CRP is the next step in AI explainability and offers entirely new possibilities in terms of investigating, testing and improving the functionality of AI models. We are already very excited to apply our new method to large language models like ChatGPT."

It is way too easy as a youth to get caught up in the idea that maths == accountancy == computer stuff == boring, because that is the idea you get from popular TV shows, because the people who write and produce such things generally have very little experience of the world outside their bubbles, and far too many people take television seriously as experience of the world, when it is almost entirely silly crap created by very limited human beings.

The national problem with maths is that most, including the top of government and FT journalists, confused arithmetics and maths. It's impossible to remove abstraction from maths. Yes it's applicable to real world problems, for reasons that puzzle philosophers and mathematicians.

text:
School maths is, for a very long time, single step or very few steps problems. When it becomes a large multi-step problem where the rules of all the small problems needs to be considered together, it becomes a seemingly laborious problem and that's the crossroads where we lose some people and others thrive. I lost my way at this point at school, but picked it up again years later to do science undergrad and masters. Makes a big difference when you are clear what you are aiming for. 
Talk about maths, we do turn out a useful crop of maths + further maths and maths based science going to Uni. But we do have a greater problem with MFL.

text: I used to be one of those who claimed "I hate maths" and "I just can't do maths" throughout my entire childhood up until I started my A-Levels. I had always wanted to pursue Computer Science since I was young, and it wasn't until I had to pick my A-Level options that I realised Maths was a crucial aspect of the field. So I reluctantly decided to take the course, and now I'm currently studying Mathematics and Computer Science as my degree. I began to admire mathematics when I "forced" myself to be interested in it. In doing so I actually came to realise the importance of the field and how it can be applied to almost anything (especially in this digital era) in the real world. If it was up to me, I'd introduce more applications of mathematics into curriculums, as that's what truly showed me the elegance and significance of the subject, and ultimately induced me into pursuing my joint honours degree rather than just Computer Science.

text: Hi, being from Asia (Singapore), I would like to know what is  marks out of 100 for the passing grade 4 ? What's the passing marks ? 50/ 100 ? 60/100? Our GCE "O" level grades are A1, A2, B3, B4, C5, C6, D7, E8 and F9. Grade C 5 and C6 are the lowest passing mark/ grade. D is below passing marks, and grade E & F are fail. Grade A1 is 75/100 and above marks, A2 is from 70 to 74. Grade C6 is 50 to 54 marks (which is the lowest passing marks for the exam on a subject ... 50/100).  For our maths subjects in primary school, we were taught to memorise the multiplication tables, and our maths teacher would sometimes start the maths class with a mental sum mini test. However, with technology, we now tend to use our brains less and rely more and more on the convenience of technology and there seem there's no need to memorise the multiplication tables anymore.

text:
I worry about another issue you have missed.  As someone that is a bio-mathematician over 40 years (ie I develop core ML algorithms and analytical tools) I see that society in the UK considers me strange if I talk about my work - someone that does worthless work and has no relevance to society.  If I go to Germany or Japan they consider me a useful person and ask me about my work.
I know that is the other end of the scale you talking about here, but I worry that we have all been told for years to "ignore the experts", don't consider the data when looking at stuff has resulted in a UK society that thinks "not knowing maths" is a good thing as people are force feed from the media that maths is stupid.  The problem is what people are told by people of influence in the UK, while in German and Japan STEM is presented as important and part of society.

I have learned that this is how I attempt to formulate and calculate art and design. I have no doubt you can approach athletics and music etc this way too. Also blinking challenges your memory on the subject and also makes you appear less like a lizard/terminator machine.

Ah, just ideas to share. Don't dull those fuzzy forms. Sharpen them, standardize them, learn, work and have fun. It's your mental toolset.

text:
If the UK Government turns math to a new "gold", I am sure the UK kids will suddenly up their skills in math.  
At the moment, UK people can do well in life without good math background required for further education at the university level; so, why would they be worried about math? 

Why China, South Korea or Hongkong are very good at math? That is how their societies work. Failing to get a good university degree in those countries, you will end up being "labor" class such as plumber, construction labor, electrician, train deriver, bus driver, etc. And those trade skills or public service got extremely low relative wage compared to UK. I'm talking about a relative wage gap here, say a mid-level accountant  or nurse with a University degree in those countries would earn at least more than three times of a full-time plumber out of high-schools; a skillful plumber here in UK would normally earn more than nurse or mid-level accountant, I think. And to get to a university, good math skill is essential.  In a way,  math is "gold" in those countries.   Everyone in those countries will want to get a shot to grab that "gold".

text: Mathematics needs to be presented more as a language, a way of thinking - we use vocabulary to describe experiences and concepts. But not many of us associate numbers/ operations as having ‚Äòreal-world‚Äô implications. It is one thing stating this, and another to practically implement it in a classroom curriculum. A restructuring of the curriculum may involve sectioning the syllabus into chapters that deal with solving real-world problems (climate change modelling, stock market modelling, etc may be contained in one chapter for example) and presenting mathematical tools as ways of solving these problems. This presents a variety of opportunities for different students to pick up the core mathematical skills based upon their specific interests (that stem from other school subjects, increasing engagement within them as well). Providing links/ associations to other school subjects students ‚Äòmore naturally‚Äô enjoy may better integrate maths into education, rather than isolating it as a subject composed of abstract rules/ notation. (Studying masters in theoretical physics and tutor GCSE/ A-level maths :))

author: @MrEzMs

text:
A great video.
I took double maths A Level in 71 and studied engineering science. After working as an engineer for almost 50 years I retired and am now a volunteer tutor at a secondary school. As an A level student I tutored a girl whose parents had moved her from a state primary to a private school. My observation from these experiences is that before doing maths it is vital that addition multiplication and fractions are mastered and firmly embedded.
It is like teaching philology to children whose reading skills are poor, it confuses them and pulls up the shutters.
To erect a building you need sound foundations this is as true for a house as for the most complicated multi story structures. Foundations are hidden and not at all sexy but without them a lifetime of pain ensues.
I believe that mathematicians are not best placed to set the maths curriculum. Not that elegant maths should not be taught but it should be introduced at a time when children are receptive and not earlier.
One of the year nines I tutored yesterday said something interesting in that while we do the topics she understands then but during maths tests she has no idea of what they are asking. It doesn't help that at the end of KS3 her skills are not even KS2.
I think that there is something in the US and European system where pupils should not progress in a subject until they have mastered the years work.

text:
In my maths class in secondary school in the UK students were required to hold up a card with the correct answer to a maths question the teacher would ask. If a student(s) got the answer incorrect he would single them out for ridicule in front of the whole class. The teacher must have concluded this was acceptable since he was getting the rest of the class to ridicule those with the incorrect answers, not doing it himself, although he required everyone to participate in attempting to answer the questions. This was in the 1990s. If you have to teach by fear, your ability to communicate technical principles is insufficient for the role of teacher. It also degrades the mental integrity of those you teach, resulting in lower potential output.

Children can be taught anything to a competent level at an early age, with varying levels of success depending on the child's cognitive abilities and the method of teaching used.

text:
Much of the maths taught in schools is irrelevant to many career paths, and the emphasis placed on a maths qualification is setting students up to fail.
I attempted maths O'level three times when aged 16 and 17, and failed each time.
I have subsequently gone on to achieve a C&G in Electronics, followed by a B.Ed, and love playing with numbers. In these situations, the maths I needed was relevant, but there is much on the maths curriculum that I have never needed to revisit.
Teaching basic numeracy and financial literacy must be part of the core curriculum, but cover other maths skills within the subjects they apply to, e.g., trigonometry in Geography, equations in Physics.
If I hadn't had belief in my own abilities, I would have just given up on anything that involved maths. I have also, subsequently, discovered that I have ADHD and ASC, which may also account for my lack of ability in maths at school.
Any time I need a novel maths solution nowadays, I use Google.

text: Former Maths teacher and current tutor. Irrespective of the curriculum, the only silver bullet I can see to raise standards is to structure the educational system to allow maths learners to learn at there own pace. As soon the 'class' pace gets ahead of a student, the vicious spiral begins of low confidence and low motivation. As soon as a student gets to learn at their own pace, with constant feedback and emotional support (i.e. it is ok to get something 'wrong' the first time, as long as we try to learn from it), most students I have helped begin to make steady progress. Unfortunately, structuring the educational system in this way, including providing for support to 18 and lifelong adult education, will take a greater proportion of national income. I would suggest though that human capital is the engine room of real economic growth so it would reasonable to borrow to fund this investment.

text: I come from a different teaching system where emphasis was not put on connecting maths to the real word. Maths was just maths, numeracy and abstract concepts alike. One thing that was different was the amount of homework given‚Ä¶ dozen of thousands of exercises every year hours on end. Maths is also about patterns, about repetition about incremental variations and incremental progress. Here you jump from one topic to another with a minimum of practice on the current learning. Pupils are not being given the chance to struggle and overcome struggle and fear through practice. Yes, practicing is boring and motivating can be difficult but way too many times the benefits of repetition and practice are ignored. Maths teaching is moving too fast in earlier stages. There are not enough exercise books and those existent are slim and offer too little to work on for each topic. No one talks about the means of the Asian maths success. It is simple: hours of practice and independent study (for those aged at equivalent GCSE and A levels). Just check for the Korean studying hours ‚Ä¶

text: Weirdly, one of my most memorable early experiences of directly using maths I had learned consciously in the real world, was when as a student having worked for a small travel company, I got cheap passage on QE2 across the atlantic. Each day there was a sweepstake on how far we had sailed mid day to mid day at a dollar a go. A screen in the cabin gave me the mid-day position and that a 10 am the next day, when the entry had to be handed in. A bit of trigonometry and a little extrapolation and I won two different days, netting around $200 extra spending money! I agree that making maths as close to relatable 'real world' problems is key, especially in the tricky GCSE years...

text:
as a maths and physics undergraduate, I‚Äôm all for the split in mathematics, having a core/practical maths and a more pure/abstract maths would serve students well I think. Day to day there actually isn‚Äôt much use for understanding higher level maths concepts, however they‚Äôre crucial and lay the foundation for many jobs based in engineering, programming, finance, data analysis, etc. Any student hoping to peruse a career in any of those subjects MUST have a strong understanding of high level fundamental maths concepts, however the majority of the population, simply won‚Äôt have any use for them, so by instead focusing on practical applications that‚Äôre often used day to day, students will likely be more engaged, or at least have a better appreciation for the utility of the subject, and more importantly, be able to aptly apply mathematical skills when needed.

 I think there also needs to be a fundamental change in our process of teaching mathematics. Maths cannot be taught like history or biology, there needs to be a much bigger focus on understanding proofs, logic, and derivations. With our current curriculum students aren‚Äôt pushed to understand maths concepts, only use them, and far too little time goes into explaining why it works. It seems some educators believe that trying to explain the derivation of formulas would only confuse students, particularly those struggling already, but I reckon the reason they‚Äôre struggling is because they haven‚Äôt been shown why it works in the first place! the UKMT does a great job of this, their challenges are full of much more practical questions with a much stronger reliance on simple logic rather than abstract mathematical concepts, actually displaying the power of rational thinking and some basic algebra, geometry, and numeracy skills and how it can solve day to day problems. 

that‚Äôs just what I reckon though

text:
I absolutely loved the interview with Professor Coles! He was so engaging and enthusiastic about his subject, and I completely agreed with him about giving students who perhaps don't 'seem' like they would enjoy maths, at least the opportunity to look at and try different areas of the subject which they may actually end up enjoying and having fun with. That being said, I also really loved the idea of creating two different subjects - Functional Maths and 'Academic' Maths - in line with the English Literature and English Language subjects which we currently have in schools.

Perhaps they could be named slightly differently, such as 'Practical Mathematics' and 'Creative Mathematics', to interest students more and prevent a class bias? And, just as with English Language and English Literature, both routes should be taught to all children (as Professor Coles notes) to ensure that those in worse-off areas are not left behind.

Fantastic documentary FT, this really got me thinking about and interested in maths again! Thank you!

text: As a maths graduate, my view is that maths is a subject where it's really important that you don't get behind... In other school subjects, you sort of jump around and can learn different topics which are more contained within themselves, filling in gaps of knowledge later. With maths, everything sort of builds on top of itself. I think a lot of students find maths very difficult because they don't have super solid understanding of the stuff previously learnt, and so new stuff is even harder to pick up. In order to 'survive' maths you really need to go back to the part where your understanding starts getting sketchy and go from there, but there's not much scope for this during a school year.
author: @olliert4840

text:
On a wider scale I think we are seriously failing children who simply aren't ready to do their GCSEs at age 14-16, because we haven't prepared them. 

I recently worked in a state school in a very poor area, and it was clear to me that even though their living situations had forced them to grow up much faster in some ways (lots of young carers, kids looking after younger children, having to deal with knife crime and gangs), they had a very naiive and childlike understanding of school. 

Many of them seemed to only come to the realization that their GCSEs determined their futures in the last few months before the exams. They'd beg for help in a panic when they were already years behind where they should have been and it was very depressing how hopeless they ended up.

The breadth of content in GCSEs has increased so much since I did my own, it was no surprise that struggling children couldn't keep up. There was no time to focus on bringing them up to the level they needed to be at, because teachers had to move on to the next topic and then the next and the next with no time to pause and consolidate much of the knowledge.

author: @august44_

text:
I have to say the vast swathes of this documentary does little to clearly explore the issues of the education structures.

For instance, using numeracy to describe functional maths skills is misleading,as it implies a mastery of the 4 basic functions to be the necessary aspect of mathematics, but also throws in concepts like decimals and percentages which are abstractions of shape and space concepts, not just numeracy concepts.

The notion of functional maths is inherently flawed as a means of solution, because it attempts to detach the linear progression of mathematical structures, in an arbitrary manner, without forethought as to what functional skills would look like- which the Bristol Professor helpfully highlights is Statistics- in the future.

This amounts to a documentary focused on fixing  a historic issue, which will inevitably rear its head again, if this focus on 'functional maths' occupies the discussion of the divide in ability experienced across the UK.

The Lord touting his lack of understanding for the utility of quadratics is another example of this, since it demonstrates that people cannot see the function of the tools they have, because the structures of education cannot 'waste' time providing it.

Ultimately, there are greater issues in education, let alone mathematics, than simply 'how do we reduce the friction of abstract thinking broadly'.
There are problems in the transition from primary to secondary, teachers have a limited understanding of where students are at, so result in a slow down in years 7/8, as content is repeated.
Trainee teachers have a high variance of success; based upon mentor figure; drastically changing their ability to enter the teaching market.
Teacher training schemes have grossly variant requirements, even when trainee's are performing the same role.

Moving back to Maths focused issues, it is a uniquely isolated subject from all others at school, largely due to other disciplines failing to appropriately utilise the language of maths within their field, in part due to historic maths anti-bias.

I could rant forever about the issues I've seen, but suffice to say; this documentary broadly fails to demonstrate the relatability of maths as a language, because the presenter does not know how to do that, so their exploration of the topic at best repeats the mistakes of the past, at worse causes exacerbated anxiety in parents who cannot parse the more immediate issues preventing their children's success.

This is both a macro and a micro problem, but like the topics in maths, the links between those issues are broadly missing in this piece.

Aight rant over, I'm not majorly accurate, just wanted to vent.
author: @sgtDrumriX

text:
I have nothijng against maths, which is a crucial subject.
But I've been abysmally bad at the subject since I started secondary school aged 10. I could do simple calculations and arithmetic then and I haven't improved my level since. I haven't needed to, thank goodness.
I have met others like me who can't do maths, one of the reasons being a feeling of loathing. I get irritated when I hear about maths anxiety: maths phobia is closer to the truth and it's the word used for instance ein France (my country).
And people agonise about falling levels in maths, so many of them tell us "this is how to overcome your maths anxiety".... On this, I have three comments:
1) the people who offer these solutions are good at maths and (probaly) enjoy the subject. How can they understand, if they've never felt the horror?
2) they all suggest different recipes. So which one if the right one? 
3) if there really was a way of overcoming maths phobia, then problem would have disappeared long ago. Instead of which we have a number of people for whom one or another of the recipes might work... 
But no-one asks the most important question: what is it abvout maths that makes so many people hate or fear it? I've never heard of people loathing geography or history, or literature. They may dislike those subjects but maths is in a class of its own. Why?

Until we know, levels will keep on falling.

text:
I remember that as a 12 year old being introduced to 'modern maths'. There were all sorts of things included in the curriculum that I have used as an adult. It was such a shame, and such a missed opportunity for the school and teachers, that none of the practical real-world applications for the concepts were explained at the time.

For example, we were taught to work in binary. Despite the fact that we had a visit to the computer department of a very large international business, no-one took the opportunity to link the lessons in binary with computers. I think there was some throw-away comment in one lesson about how computers used binary - but that was it! No expansion about procedural decision-making in a yes-no or positive-negative systems - that was all left for the penny dropping moment years later as an adult.

I started secondary school in 1966! Little has changed regarding the outcomes of either numeracy or literacy in schools in the interceding period.
