text:
Maths was never a problem for me, but it also had a purpose for me, I was using it in my other subjects, design & technology, computing, physics, etc.
I think that's part of the problem - it being too abstract. But I think the other part of the problem is the image, that it's too hard, that it's just for nerds, that you'll never use it because you'll always have a calculator with you, and I think too much emphasis is put on getting the right number over using the right methods (or using any method that would work).
What demoralised me when doing maths papers was certain teachers not bothering to read my working out, and just giving me 0 marks if I got the wrong number at the end. I've read the mark schemes for those papers, and you're not supposed to just look at that final number. Anyway, I had some good teachers towards the end, and they said that outside of Uni, A-level maths was the hardest maths I'd ever do. I still do maths at work, and yep, what I do hasn't come close to that. So maybe it's also set at an impractical level.

text: I'm 17, I took my GCSE maths exam in 2022. I found mathematics hellish. It's haunted me my entire life, I'm genuinely interested in Computer Science but I'm hindered by my Grade 4 (C) Pass grade at GCSES. Any choices I have in the future now were dictated by my state school mathematics lessons, we weren't taught to love maths like I'm starting to now, we were taught to chance it and get a lucky pass grade at a Foundation Exam. Even though I passed, most universities require a B, which was unobtainable for the papers I sat, again, which I had no choice but to sit. Something has to change for the better, Maths is pure, problem-solving awesome, but the classes were dire, unimaginative and were mostly taught by part-time PE teachers my school had available. Just because we hadn't unlocked our skills as fast as everyone else, we were given nothing to work with or for, and better yet, became ridiculed by staff and other students constantly for not progressing. We deserve better than this, and so do the minority of passionate Maths teachers left, always on ludicrously low wages. Sort out your schools Britain.
author: @BugCatcherEd

text: Anyone who discusses education and focuses purely on Secondary education is probably missing a trick. The SATs at the end of UK primary education pressure schools into cramming specific maths and English skills with their students. It is at this age that I have seen students decide that 'I can't do maths'. For instance, there is a huge focus on memorising times tables and solving equations quickly, because they have a timed exam looming. Children who find it hard to memorise abstract lists of numbers 'fail' at these timed maths tasks (in class and in homework) over and over again. But how much of the maths we use as an adult is done as a race against the clock? This is just one example of the distorting and demoralising impact of SATs on students' view of maths.
author: @BiscuitGeoff

text:
I feel like nobody is mentioning an important point. All of the STEM fields are built up block by block into an upside down pyramid of knowledge. If you're missing blocks further down, understanding new concepts further up becomes utterly bewildering and demotivating. 

The vast majority of students at some point miss a building block, and everything thereafter must be rote memorisation. How uninspiring. I'm not saying its necessary for every child to grasp the fundamentals of the universe from the start. But our system should guide children to learn and comprehend at their own pace, rather than squeezing cohorts through a 'rote memorisation funnel' wholesale. Coming out such a funnel without adequate comprehension, and then being exposed to new concepts, makes people feel stupid and incapable well before their actual cognitive ceiling.
author: @binishulman8655

author: @chandniku1770

text:
Honestly, before they think about maths at the higher ages, they should investigate how children progress at primary levels. I did work experience at a primary school and I had to do extra reading with children who were struggling to read (5-6 year olds) and a lot of the kids who were struggling just needed someone who was willing to be patient to let them sound out the words and think about the context of what was happening in the text (while not making them feel embarrassed for not being fast enough). When they got it on their own (admittedly after a while), it was amazing to see how those kids became more confident and lit up. Often, there is just not enough time for those kids and they just get left behind. As a result they just disengage and stop trying to learn because they can't keep up. 

I remembered this because now that I'm studying maths at uni, I have really underestimated the power of reading and comprehension, especially for tricky maths questions (that are now put into real life contexts) and I just think that our foundations in reading and learning how to learn are  just too weak. It's only now, at uni, that I have realised that I don't know how to learn and think for myself. I am only starting to learn to think critically and use what I have to solve harder questions (break down problems and solve them in parts). I was super lucky to have parents who were willing to invest time into securing those foundations at home, but I am aware that a lot of families don't because they lack the resources, time or confidence to do so.

text: I was a teenager who went through an English high school maths education as an undiagnosed autistic with ADHD. I excelled in English and the humanities, even in the sciences I was a high performer. In the Maths classroom, however, I found myself in an environment that was impatient, hostile, and humiliating. My teachers never made an effort to make the lessons interesting, but they would always make an effort to humiliate me whenever they had the chance to do so. You weren't listening for a moment? Get out the class. You get a question wrong? Get out the class. There was one teacher who i had for Maths who i hated and who hated me, and he made my life in that classroom a living hell (he would later turn out to be a pedophile, which was an unpleasant revelation). Years after that experience i went through life under the assumption that i had no maths aptitude, all because some shitty teachers convinced me that i had no ability in the subject. In contrast, my Humanities and English teachers were always very nice, patient, and encouraging. I don't think it's a coincidence that i excelled in the classes that were positively reinforcing and patient. I think that, were maths classes more patient, encouraging, and inclusive of different minds, instead of prone to making an example of the outliers, then more people wouldn't be afraid of it

text: I think a large part of the problem is with teachers. For most of my secondary education I was stuck with math teachers that were old gits who clearly didn't give a damn about teaching nor about mathematics, and who seemed to hold a great resentment for the classes they taught. Then in my 3rd year I got a new maths teacher who was very enthusiastic not only about maths but about seeing to it that we students were actually taking the information on board and understand things fully. I slowly began to unlearn my hatred for maths and actually quite enjoyed it. Sadly I had to leave school with almost no attendence in my 4th year due to health complications and ever since I've been wishing that like many of my other subjects I could've kept going. That's the difference a good teacher makes.

author: @jackwalls2448

text:
The GCSE is a pointless qualification, as are all non-normalised, subjectively prize awarding exercises. Might as well do away with the alpha/numeric grades and randomly award a "Lovely", "Smashing", "Great", ... or a "Wibble", "Foo", "Boo", ... to the pupils, as just as meaningful, and open to gaming, and grade-inflation. Given a 1988, just above cohort-median, GCSE grade E would easily translate to a 2023 grade 5. If serious about competing in the World, an IQ test at puberty (~13) would as accurately capture an individuals FLUID intelligence ( ability to learn ), would permit pupils to be streamed into "not to be left with glue, scissors, or glitter", "has potential, if encouraged", "is capable of great things, with or without us", ... . The next 5+ years could then be dedicated to maximising potentials, rather than chasing worthless grades.

FYI: Most pupils didn't "sit O'Level". In the mid 80s, and excluding Scotland, where virtually nobody sat O'Level: ~20% were entered for O'level, ~40% CSE, ~40% were entered for neither. When the GCSE was introduced in 1988, 30% of pupils were still not entered for the exam, and of those who sat the one of the competing flavours of assessment, the MEDIAN grade was E, equating to ~25% of the cohort obtaining a C or better, in 2023 over 60% nominally achieve the notional equivalent grade 4, though the kids are no smarter, as seen by their scores in external international tests.
author: @AndrewRoberts11

text:
I'm disheartened that it takes a legacy of disaster for a conservative politician to realize the error of their ways.

But it makes me hopeful that the modern curriculum that seems so ubiquitous is being recognized for the primitive disaster it is.

Modern schools should prioritize all of the following before trigonometry:
1) Relationships and attachment (i.e., how to create healthy relationships and active focus on doing so with parents, teachers and peers... See Gordon Neufeld) 
2) Personal health and well being
3) Career exploration
4) Personal finance
5) Workplace laws & safety 
6) Immediately relevant personal student issues and how to address them (with adult guidance) 
7) How to tackle important life milestones (e.g., passport applications, driver's licenses, social security numbers, getting hired, accessing legal aid, changimg a flat tire, renting an apartment, etc.)
7) Why inept people (mostly men) are in charge of things they don't understand
8) Why you will never own a house or be able to afford rent and why that's not a problem in Switzerland

I think each student should have monthly psychological evaluations and all teaching should revolve around successfully achieving good mental health and healthy attachments above all else.
author: @blakebeaton8410

text: We need to remember that examples should relate to real life; no more questions of the type "if a man and a half digs a hole and a half etc." I well remember at school, 70 years ago, thinking the man who left the plug out of the bath, but still wanted to know how long it took to fill was a fool. There are much better ways of teaching practical examples from life. Our main way of thinking and of communicating is via words and our descriptions of mathematical operations must be translatable into mathematical symbols. Thus expressions such as thee times less than  should not be used. Teaching numeracy related to real life is key.
author: @raymondrowe160

text: I did Maths A Level, and got an A grade, despite going on to study English at university - I'm sure Sunak would love me. Yet, when I got my first payslip, a month or so after completing said A Level Maths, I had no idea how to read it. I'd never seen one before. I sat there for 5 minutes trying to understand it. The numbers looked like they might make sense, but I had no idea what that meant practically - whether I was being payed what I was supposed to be, or not. I took a photograph of it, and sent it to my dad for help. Thankfully, he was able to help me understand, and I gradually got to the point where, a few months later, I was able to notice where something had gone wrong with my pay, and work out why. But my A Level Maths had nothing to do with it. Teaching Maths to age 18 is not going to solve issues like not understanding payslips if there are not fundamental changes in how that maths is taught, because at the moment, people who are studying maths to 18 can still have these issues.
author: @victoriab8186

text: A system which says that you are not allowed to fail, but which enforces failure on 30% of the population, is a system which is going to consistently make life worse for 30% of people. Maybe lets fix the institutional issues in our finance systems which make things so hard to understand that you need seriously good maths skills just to work out if you are being payed correctly. Lets fix the issues in our systems which lead to people being left behind, rather than telling all the kids who are bad or even pretty decent at maths that there is something wrong with them for not having got 'further' with maths, or for not wanting maths to be central to their lives.

Can we not lower our standards to the lowest common denominator for once? 

He also mentions "we need to teach gross vs net, %'s and margins" well I'm sorry Lord Baker, not all of the kids are going into business. Let's teach general mathematics and have the domain specific maths appear in those classes. Business/Economics classes should teach gross vs net, margins etc.

author: @Scott30_

text:
21:33 Everyone conflates maths with arithmetic and numeracy these days. The East Asian model insists on everyone following the same pace, which stunts the growth of precocious mathematicians. There is also a fixation on the end results, and exotic techniques for very specific problems, and ignores proofs and the wider landscape. Students practice endlessly on the same highly specific problems. As a result, China, and to a similar extent Korea and Vietnam, are underrepresented in terms of top mathematicians.

On the other end of the spectrum, there are traditional maths powerhouses like France and Russia. Education there tend to overgeneralise maths problems, through a philosophical and metaphysical lens. There is an emphasis on producing top mathematicians over informing the general public, who are left on their own.

The difference between the two maths cultures is best crystallised in a Chinese/Soviet joke. A foreign ambassador visits a French primary school, and asks a pupil what the result of 2+3 is. The boy replies, "I don't know, but it must be 3+2 because integers under addition form an abelian group, i.e. commutative."

It follows from this that if Britain was to discontinue having 12 subjects studied at secondary school level, only one of which is maths, and instrad make all 12 subjects mathematics on some variant then our maths scores would improve, but does anybody in their right mind believe that our performance as a nation would improve? 

Britain will not be undone by some youngsters  having poor maths skills. It will be undone by a stubborn refusal to pay careful attention to the facts.

So even those like me could leave school numerate - even if clueless about a quadratic equation. Incidentally I think the reason for that was that I found the maths subjects abstract and couldn‚Äôt see the practical application, whereas it was obvious for Arithmetic. Go to a shop and buy something ¬£6.72 and give the person at the till ¬£12.22 and see the look you will get and the... YOU game me TOO much money... What do I do? What do I do? What do I do? 
You have to tell them, can you count how much I gave you? Enter that amount in the till... and how much change does it give. (Change ¬£5.50)

My parents taught me to Read and Count to 100 before age 4 and by my fourth birthday, I was taught basic addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. 
Illiterate and innumerate parents can not teach children how to do things they can not do.

text:
Sometimes the reason why maths can be so difficult, challenging and daunting is because, sometimes it's the way it's taught and not everyone learns the same way as everyone else.
This is why I do think a radical reform of the education system needs to be sorted out and addressed.

But also, I don't think anyone has ever thought about this concept, as to why some people don't understand maths even into adulthood.
That some or a lot of people can have what's called Dyscalculia, which is Dyslexia's lesser-known sibling.

Dyscalculia (Mathematics) - Dyslexia (Reading & Writing)

Dyscalculia symptoms can include but are not limited to.

Typical symptoms include:


*Difficulty counting backwards.

*Difficulty remembering 'basic' facts.

*Slow to perform calculations.

*Weak mental arithmetic skills.

*A poor sense of numbers & estimation.

* Difficulty in understanding place value.

*Addition is often the default operation.

*High levels of mathematics anxiety.

This can or could be a neurological condition in the brain that again, can or could be the culprit and as to why certain people struggle with mathematics as a whole, not just the basics.

But the question is, where do you go to get diagnosed if you do have dyscalculia and how much would it cost?

text:
The idea that so many people express of how useless mathematics as taught in school is to your career and life in general. Beyond some basic language skill and arithmetic every topic I was taught in school classes has been useless to me.

Dates, people and events in history never came up at a job interview. Geology and the regions of the UK or climate of the equator was never needed. But no one has the right to tell me what I can and can not learn. If I have the facility to understand something why should it only be topics that make me a better industrial worker? What I do with the knowledge I was taught and much more I discovered in books and out of the class room is up to me and yes sometimes I need help. 

Post 16, when students go onto more vocational training they have had 10 years at failing in arithmetic and mathematics. It has been acceptable for them to fail more so than failure in English is. Even teachers in their roll as tutor express the view that they too found mathematics difficult and "never go it." Many teaching mathematics have limited training in mathematics, are not a mathematics specialised even if having done a level of mathematics in their degrees beyond basic GCSE. It does not make them bad teachers and many themselves had to overcome shortfalls in their own education but you would not expect A Level physics or chemistry to be taught by someone who failed these subjects at GCSE level. You can be asked to teach mathematics and English on the understanding that you will work to getting at least a GCSE in the subject. The time available to teach repeat GCSE mathematics classes is cut back to perhaps 90 minutes or 2 hours per week for two terms. 10 years of a mind set to fail can not be overcome when the one to one interaction is limited to a few minutes a week.

author: @vansf3433

text:
I have read many different books of mathemstics, and found that what make such human- invented concepts and notions of mathematics difficult to people come from either messy methods of teaching or ambiguous languages, which can make simple concepts and notions of mathematics confusing or complicated to many, and when they don't understand them, they tend to avoid them. As a result, their knowledge of such human -invented concepts and notions are rather poor. 
What can improve such educational problems is to change the current methods of teaching to methods of teaching with closer to the real physical world and everyday life, which are known to everyone, instead of staying within the narrow world of abstract notions which are obvious expressions of ignorance of human mathematicians who use such ambiguity to hide or cover up their own fundamental misunderstandings of human -invented defective concepts and notions of mathematics. A good teacher of mathemstics must know how to explain complicated concepts and notions in simple 
and  unambigous language with examples from daily life, familiar with everyone. It can be said that the way how you use the language, and how to understand such human-invented concepts and notions objectively, but not blindly fanatically, will determine whether you can successfully pass on the knowledge of mathematics to people or not

text:
I put myself down as slightly above the average in terms of maths, but in no way near the top. I had awful teachers in school for maths, and the only reason I got an B in maths was because I played video games, I liked to build things and figure out WHY they worked, not just what the parts are called and what they looked like.
Modern school is about learning concepts and formulas, and being able to cram enough info in hopes you have to repeat some of it on the pages of an exam. None of it is about understanding the concepts, and why they're important.
Only reason I care about, and understand pythagorus is because of a videogame I play. Only reason I understand some algebra and Ohms law is because of odd bits and bobs I built.
Kids need a reason to care beyond 'because I said so'.
And the mention that kids in other countries play numbers games and we don't is on point. Even a basic game like marbles can teach kids about angles, which can go on to teach about refraction,. Or games like conkers can teach about addition whereby if one conker moves and another stays still the impact will be at x m/s, but if both move it will be at x*2 m/s.
If kids never play, or have experiances to relate to maths, or any other subject for that matter, then of course they won't undersrtand, because humans were never evolved to learn in a classroom. A classroom isn't the be all end all of learning, its the space you use to reflect, conceptulise, and abstract what you've learnt from experience.
author: @sonny0jim

text:
This is not a problem in the UK alone, and it is not about testing nor high-level policy.

In high school, we are only allowed to teach mathematics following the tradition. At the first sight of seemingly harder maths, parents will complain that we make their kids look unskilled.

As with most disciplines, there is a talent component to learning mathematics. Less talented students will find another (equally important) discipline to master, and this is a good thing. Panic and stress should be addressed by the people who are actually trained for that (not me), and not by lowering the bar at the expense of the average student.

Unless you are really talented, mathematics is going to be hard work for you. No amount of good teaching practices can change this. So maybe we are becoming less used to put in the hard work? 

Teachers are overworking, underpaid, and undervalued by society. No wonder that we are only left with either good colleagues who take teaching as a mission (not extremely common), or colleagues who pass on their frustrations to their students.

I feel I should apologise in advance  this is an issue that I feel strongly about, so this is a long comment 

There is an irony in Lord Baker saying that the system needs replacing. When he oversaw its introduction, the majority of teachers saw that it was flawed. It also annoys me that comparison is made with Asian countries. They are taught by rote. Individual thinking is discouraged. I've taught students from Korea, Japan, and China, whose parents were here for post-graduate courses. They had memorised whole text books, but I'm fairly sure that few of them would have coped with a question set in a different way. Probably the greatest strength of teaching in England is a willingness to think outside the box, to be imaginative, and to question what they have been taught.

I was a teacher for 35 years, though not a maths teacher. However, I often used to cover for absent maths teachers. I used to get annoyed with the students at first, always asking for help, being unwilling to take their own decisions.

One day, a thought struck me. I noticed, during a lesson with a lower set, where they were supposed to be answering questions on fractions, that the majority of the class simply could not visualise fractions. I decided to abandon the work set, and despite not being a maths teacher, I handed out some paper and scissors, which we then used to create concrete fractions. I was shocked that the class responded so well. They began doing calculations similar to the ones that they had seen in the textbook. They soon became enthusiastic to start the questions that they had been set, and I persuaded them to complete them all at home.

A couple of days later, the class teacher came to ask me about the lesson as she did not understand why the whole class had achieved 90% or more on the work. She thought that I must have given them the answers. I didn't mind her thinking that we had cheated, but I was annoyed when she was surprised at the truth. 

It has to be said that part of the trouble with a lot of maths teachers is their complete inability to understand that not everyone is as numerate as they are themselves. They often make assumptions that everyone enjoys maths the same way that they do. As an outsider in the maths classroom, even though I am numerate, it was obvious to me that there was something wrong, not with the students, but with the way they were expected to do work that appears simple, but is difficult for them. I realised why, as they left the room, several of the class asked if I could be their maths teacher. After this experience, I never held back, but if they struggled I would take the set work down to something that they understood. As the video said, a huge problem is that students experience failure too much. I gave them a tiny success that made them feel that they were not stupid

text:
I loved maths, but it was hard. I got a C in O level maths, a C in additional maths and a C in A level maths in 1984. I‚Äôve always worked with computers, and I find that core abilities are paramount. To be able to manipulate numbers - be it in your head or on paper - is not just useful, it‚Äôs essential.  I find that out of all the sub-skills of number manipulation, the ability to estimate, or to sanity-check other results, is the single most important. Let the machines get the exact answer when it‚Äôs needed.  At other times, being able to estimate the correct answer quickly is more useful. And being able to get machines to give approximate answers is also relevant: it‚Äôs no use saying that you have to walk 623.142857m to the corner shop when ‚Äòabout 600m‚Äô is arguably easier to process and more relevant.

And I have to say that I‚Äôve probably used quadratic equations, Pythagoras, integration or differentiation probably once or never in my last 30+ years of work.  But being able to understand them, as well as where logarithms and exponentiation come into everyday things is to my mind, not to be understated.

author: @george6977

text:
Anyone who says it‚Äôs the approach math is taught or graded with is an idiot. The real issue is perception. For generations math has been held up as this nebulous difficult subject that only a select few who ‚Äòget it‚Äô can enter. And people will do what people will do: they deride those who are naturally gifted and proceed to be afraid of ever tackling the issue. I see this all the time with my high school kids. All their lives they have been told that math is beyond them, so I have to spend a lot of time peeling away those biases so that they have a chance to succeed. These biases persist because most people will never use anything more than an elementary level of math. As a result, anything higher is kept at arms length and feared. Society reinforces these ideas all the time. It is no mystery why the West has a math problem. 

The same cannot be said for those in Eastern countries. They are told that math is hard, but that if they work at it they will succeed. They are shown examples of people who need high level math every day, unlike in the US. 

Math is not hard. It has a PR problem. This is exemplified by the fact that all modern techniques for teaching math require the teacher to ‚Äòtrick‚Äô the student into learning it. This approach sidesteps the fear response that has been built up by society. If we can change our cultural approach to math, I guarantee that we will see massive changes in people‚Äôs‚Äô relationship to it.

Fortunately, during those final 2 years, new math teachers were specially hired to reform the schools mathematics department and they really sparked my love and interest for mathematics and science. Now I have a BEng in Mechanical Engineering and an MSc in Robotics.

I do believe this is all down too disparity in educational quality and resources in different regions in the UK, teaching quality, and not actually teaching students why this is useful and how it can applicable to many different parts of life.

text:
If an employee becomes unable to make ends meet because their employer doesn't cover their living costs, that has nothing to do with bad maths, and everything to do with a company failing to pay their employee what they need to work for them. In the case of a universal credit recipient.

You don't need a maths PhD (just KS3 maths) to understand that when your living expenses exceed your pay, your finances live on a deficit. Wages have failed to keep up with inflation since 2020. Universal credit has never provided enough to cover even basic living expenses for its entire 10 year existence.
A person can only operate on a deficit for so long (as long as their savings allow) before they run out of cash, before the bailiffs come in, and the bailiff activity has been at record levels in the past year.

Out-of-control inflation, low-pay, and the cost-of-living crisis has nothing to do with mathematical illiteracy and everything to do with governmental incompetence / callousness.

The part at 17:15, where Miranda & the maths teacher blames workers for failing to control their expenses, is disingenuous at best, gaslighting at worst.

text: This is a very interesting video. I attended a boys-only grammar school in the 60s. For me, maths was a nightmare. As it was only fifteen years after the end of the war there were quite a few masters, especially for maths, who were underqualified or even unqualified. As mentioned in the video the whole school curriculum was a relic of the early years of the 20th century - very inflexible and with heavy emphasis on rote learning. The style of teaching was such that either that one understood the subject matter or not, with no middle ground, because our masters were barely able to explain the core principles well, if at all. I struggled with it constantly, never understood calculus or statistics and eventually managed to pass AO level maths because I wasn't good enough to take it at A level. Ironically my two sons found the subject easy and interesting, one going on to receive a PhD! I am now in my seventies and have never had a problem with 'basic' maths/arithmetic and have never needed to use an equation since my teens.

By the time I left primary school I like everyone else in my class I had mastered the 4 arithmetic processes, vulgar fractions, decimal fractions, percentages and I knew how to calculate the areas of rectangles, triangles and circles. By the time I had completed my O levels (and I am no master mathematician as Baker would have it) I could solve quadratic equations and understood basic trigonometry. author: @redandro10

text:
The English language has 26 letters (or 52 if we take cases into account), while numerical math has just 10 digits plus some symbols. People do not feel scared on reading a news article but somehow scared of doing math. In this sense, as a language, math is even simpler than English. There is only one general way to improve people's math skill: immerse yourself into the realm. in fact, we all learn English in this way, aren't we? immersion is key to learning any language, including math. The reason we don't feel afraid of (everyday) English is simply that we immerse into it almost 24/7 since we are born. Ever since we were baby, we listen to English and learn the way it works (aka finding patterns). There shouldn't be any difference for math.

One key distinction between English and math is that we learn math in basically a linear way, which makes early immersion even more important. But at least math is not entirely linear, we have "core" and "academic" math, but I think we can also add logic into the story. Imagine if we teach high school students the pigeonhole principle, everyone in the room would probably laugh at its triviality, but it is commonly a tool you only see in theoretical math in UNIVERSITY. There are a lot of math out there that can be easily accessible to high school students even though they might be bad at calculus, for example. But yet the way we now teach math is to not teach those and focus on the more "traditional" topics.

text:
This reminds me of my childhood days in the UK (I'm Japanese but grew up in London until seven in the 80s). At the kindergarten I attended, each student was free to make their own progress in math studies, so I competed with a girl (she was also Japanese) to make more progress in math than anyone else in the class. Eventually, we completed multiplication and progressed to the division section before 1st grade, but neither of us understood the concept of division, and we ended up cheating on each other's wrong answers. Of course, the teacher noticed and scolded us for it, rightfully so. Those days were the most fun I've ever had learning math.
I had the impression that the UK is a progressive country with free learning and prestigious schools, so knowing it is weak in maths today surprised me.

author: @lilytea3

text:
Not everyone can do computation like Newton, Turing, or Bertrand Russell.

But, yes, I do see this mathematical ineptitude in the UK!

I do so many foreigners working in the City of London in finance and banking.

Most of them are called "Quants" who usually came from France in the 1980s to work in areas such as financial engineering, financial risk management or derivative trading; followed by others such as the Asians (Singaporeans/Indians/Chinese/Pakistanis/Japanese, etc.) and the Eurasian Nationalities (e.g. Russians) that do numerate degrees and settle down in the UK.

I have some silly questions to take this debate further ahead =>

-Could this be due to technological reasons? Do people in a Cold Climate struggle with numbers?

- Or is it due to something that has anything to do with the English DNA? How the English people have evolved?

- Or has this got to do something with the education policy and the way the subject is taught in the classroom? The classroom size effect is based on the teacher/student ratio, etc.

- Or is it that some Confucian societies teach students to calculate manually using the Abacus Computation Device? Modern research shows that using the Abacus System can help develop certain parts of the brain which helps students to elevate their numeracy level in applied physical sciences, and so on, etc.

- Lastly, it is how Maths is perceived. Should Maths be taught as a language (an art) or as a science? I think this distinction should be made upfront because the entire system of pedagogy changes once we classify or taxonomize a discipline.

Of course, with the advent of computing technologies, software, coding and programming languages, people tend to rely more on machines and systems, to arrive at numerical solutions to problem solving.

Anyways, this is a big debate, and the British achievements in mathematics and other physical sciences cannot be berated, but, spreading data literacy, increasing numeracy and improving computational capabilities, need an integrated approach and a new education policy.

Thank you!

text:
Learning maths WITH excel and phone calculators should be the norm.
There should be much more programming education as well.
The goal should be that at least 10% of people can have the potential to get a 6 figure job later.
Most people who were always caught up in maths would go to financial jobs like at deloitte or some bank. But those kinds of jobs you're going through maths education where you.. make proofs, learn to solve novel mathematical problems with novel kinds of mathematical tricks... 

The maths they are talking about .. are about using maths to manage your daily life. I think then just pre-chew it, make an excel sheet with them to calculate a shopping trip. Make excel sheets with students that calculates revenues and expenses for an irregular income.
Make excel sheets to display graphs, make sheets that optimize the choice of buying an item with shipping costs, and one that has a higher price but no shipping costs, then find out at which point the item with shipping costs becomes cheaper, then calculate the cost per liter.

When it comes to stats, i think probability is something everyone can learn. We need to sanitize formulas and algorythms. Some people just need them as a "recipe"
Just give them the instructions, and let them do the algorythms WITH the instructions but when teaching... USE the instructions.
Here we're given a formula collection, but in class you NEVER use it. Then when you should be using it in an exam, those formulas look completely different and you end up with thousands of question marks. If a teacher had explained why this formula looks different from the one we learned, then you could actually use that book.

But in the end, if you can do maths like applying a recipe, you're already 75% there and that's like a C

text:
Maths is extremely useful in the real world no doubt, from the financial sector i.e. monitoring investments, trading to IT a lot of these AI models use a lot of complex maths, to Instagram filters that your average teenage girl sitting in the back of maths class bored out of her mind uses, to engineering and even the defense sector i.e.  if Vladimir gets a bit trigger happy how will our modern systems fight back and a bunch of applications I haven't even mentioned, So it can be a very exciting practical subject.

However does your average maths teacher explain this, use real world examples in my case no , we simply have mediocre individuals teaching you  that if 2x=4 what is x, and when your average student in my experience quite innocently asks "when are we going to use this in real life" they are simply given a vague answer "well rocket scientists use it" or if your average teacher can't muster that up they simply accuse the student of being a trouble maker.

The whole education system needs a shake up places with higher PISA scores ie Estonia, China etc let failing schools close down by cutting off their funding, and we should make better use of tech and heaven forbid if your an adult looking to brush up on your maths skills, sure there are sites out there like EDX, Coursera and MIT open courseware but it's a hard road.

text: I have worked in 3 primary schools for over 15 years. One of the key problems is that the earliest introduction for children to maths is via arithmetic. I keep making a fuss about how many teachers, and almost all children at age 11, do not understand the rules about how our numbering system works. To test this, ask an 11 year old child WHY the hundreds column is the hundreds column, and I guarantee that very few can tell you (and very few teachers come to that), but yet this is an application of one of the fundamental rules from which everything flows. Without understanding this rule, teachers tell children that they have to use column values in arithmetic and so make it so much harder - children very early on therefore think that they are no good at maths and get turned off. Dienes apparatus reinforces this nonsense - the best place for that is the bin. Zoltan Dienes has really buggered teaching arithmetic! One of my other bugbears is that teachers tell children that multiplication is "repeated addition"! They then wonder why children get really dismayed when dealing with fractions of amounts.
